item.title: Ross_4_squares
item.description: Clarification I really learnt a lot from Ross program, one of the most impressive things is the proof for Lagrange 4-squares theorem. Statement Theorem 1.1: $\forall n\in \mathbb{Z}^+,\exists a,b,c,d\in \mathbb{Z}\ s.t.$ $$n=a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2$$

item.title: Eisenstein Like Series
item.description: Remark Th 1 is one of the exercise problems in COMPLEX ANALYSIS by E.Stein(it is the last problem before the appendix). but the book only provide sketch of the solution, so I fill in details in this note. Th 1: $r_8(n) = 16{\sigma_3}^*(n)$ where $r_8(n) = \#\left\{(x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_8)\in\mathbb{Z}^8|\sum {x_i}^2=n\right\}$ ${\sigma_3}^*(n) = \begin{cases} \sigma_3(n) & \text{n is odd}\newline \sum_{d|n}(-1)^dd^3={\sigma_3}^e(n)-{\sigma_3}^o(n) & \text{n is even} \end{cases}$ where ${\sigma_3}^e(n)=\displaystyle\sum_{d|n\atop d\ even}d^3, \quad {\sigma_3}^o(n)=\displaystyle\sum_{d|n\atop d\ odd}d^3$
